Graphical abstract The synergistic effect of the alloy phase and the oxide phase in CoFe-CoFe2O4 catalyst with cavity structure inhibited the shuttle effect and accelerated charge transfer for sulfur evolution reaction. The slow conversion of polyphase in lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries not only intensifies the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), but also causes the continuous accumulation of inactive sulfur species, resulting in rapid capacity attenuation and sluggish dynamic performance. Herein, the promoting effect of atomic interface stress on sulfur reaction was investigated via CoFe-CoFe2O4 heterogeneous nanosheets with a cavity structure. The strain force induced by the in-situ precipitation of CoFe bimetallic alloy in oxide matrix increased the d-band center, which was conducive to the interaction between catalyst and LiPSs. The sulfur cathode based on this two-dimensional (2D) nanosheet design showed an extremely high capacity of 751 mAh g−1 at 4 C. Even with a sulfur loading of 5.55 mg cm−2, its area capacity was still as high as 7.15 mAh cm−2. Meanwhile, the enhanced stability greatly improved the practical potential of Li-S batteries. Keywords 2D nanosheets In-situ precipitation Strain effect D-band center Li-S batteries 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, with very high theoretical capacity (1675 mAh g−1 for sulfur cathode) and energy density (2600 Wh kg−1), occupy a leading position in the field of new energy storage devices [1]. However, the shuttle effect caused by soluble intermediate lithium polysulfide (LiPSs) and the passivation caused by insoluble discharge product (Li2S2/Li2S) during the electrode working process cannot be ignored. The slow redox reactions of complex LiPSs, such as solid-liquid will aggravate the above two issues, affect the rapid start and cruise ability of the battery [2,3]. Especially at a high loading and a lower electrolyte vs. sulfur (E/S) ratio, an increase in the concentration and content of LiPSs further slows down the reaction kinetics [4]. To improve Li-S batteries, the introduction of porous carbon hosts into the electrodes is widely used to prevent the shuttling of LiPSs. However, carbon is a non-polar material, and its inhibition of polar LiPSs diffusion is only physical. Meanwhile, carbon nanomaterials do not have the ability to accelerate the LiPS reaction, and the effect of improving the polyphase conversion kinetics is limited [4,5]. In recent years, choosing the right catalysts in Li-S batteries is considered to be effective in alleviating the above challenges faced from various angles. Polymers, metal-organic frameworks, and inorganic compounds are the most commonly used catalytic materials reported [5–8]. Compared with the previous two, inorganic compounds represented by transition metal oxides [9] have unique advantages in the adsorption of polysulfides because of their excellent polarity with polysulfides. In particular, porous catalytic materials can provide more active sites and give full play to catalytic advantages. Although the porous transition metal oxide catalytic materials with a high surface area can inhibit the shuttle effect from both physical barrier and chemisorption of LiPSs, the slow electron conductivity will lead to the accumulation of LiPSs on the medium surface and accelerate the saturation of the adsorption site [10–12]. Meanwhile, the solid Li2S2/Li2S not only blocks the mass transfer channels, but also causes the passivation and deactivation of the reaction interface. Therefore, it is necessary to improve the charge transfer ability and catalytic activity of transition metal oxide additives to promote the rapid LiPS conversion [13]. The catalytic activity of a catalyst is closely related to its electronic structure, which can be regulated by structural defects, doping atoms, heterostructures, etc. [14,15]. These engineering methods may produce stress force, which causes the interatomic distance on the catalyst surface or locally to deviate from the standard atomic distance in the material, resulting in changes in lattice parameters, atomic spacing, and coordination bond length [16,17]. The strain effect leads to the change of orbital overlap probability of transition metal atoms, which leads to the change of d-band width and the transfer of energy level [18,19]. Reasonable catalyst modification can make the d-band center move up, and the displacement of the antibonding orbital reduces its occupancy, which increases the stability and strength of the interaction between the substrate and LiPSs [20,21]. Therefore, the d-band center of the metal element is a key index that affects the electronic structure of the catalyst and determines the interaction between the active site and LiPS. Herein, CoFe2O4 was used as an example to explore a novelty d-band center regulation technique for metal oxides to enhance LiPS reactions. As a classical cubic inverse spinel structure, Co-ion in CoFe2O4 occupies half of the Oh site, and Fe-ion occupies the other half of the Oh site. The electron jump between two different valence metals at the Oh site gives it satisfactory electrocatalytic characteristic [20]. For this work, CoFe-CoFe2O4 heterogeneous nanosheets with hollow cavity structure were prepared using CoFe2O4 as matrix. On the one hand, the CoFe bimetallic alloy was induced by the in-situ precipitation reaction of improved electrical conductivity. More importantly, the stress force between bimetallic alloy and oxide stretched the crystal surface of CoFe2O4, increased the crystal surface spacing and interatomic bond length of CoFe2O4 (Fig. 1 a and Fig. S1), and shifted the center of the d-band upward (Fig. 1b), further strengthening the connection between the LiPSs and the catalyst, thereby reducing the activation barrier [22]. On the other hand, different from the simple phase stacking, the rich atomic-bonded heterointerface formed by the in-situ preparation of CoFe-CoFe2O4 would form impurity levels and interface electric fields, which jointly promoted the rapid migration of ions and electrons [23]. In addition, as a catalytic medium for Li-S batteries (Fig. 1c, d), layered three-dimensional (3D) nanosheets provided a wealth of active sites to interact with sulfur species. The presence of numerous cavities was more conducive to locking soluble LiPSs and avoiding diffusion. As a result, sulfur cathode modified based on these heterogeneous nanosheets obtained extremely reversible capacities of 1390 and 751 mAh g−1 at 0.2 and 4 C, respectively. The attenuation rate was only ∼0.05% per cycle. Even at a higher sulfur loading of 5.55 mg cm−2, the areal capacity reached a staggering 7.15 mAh cm−2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of CoFe2O4 and CoFe-CoFe2O4 Typically, the graphene oxide (120 mg) was uniformly dispersed into 75 mL of ethylene glycol and ultrasonic treatment was performed to obtain solution A. Solution B was obtained by dispersing 1.0 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 2.0 mmol of Fe(NO3)2·9H2O into 25 mL of ethylene glycol. The two solutions A and B were mixed together and stirred at room temperature for 1.5 h. The resulting suspension was condensed and refluxed 170 °C for 2 h. After the reaction solution was cooled naturally, it was washed with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol and dried overnight under vacuum at 80 °C. Finally, the dried powder was calcined at 400 °C in air to obtain the CoFe2O4 product. For CoFe-CoFe2O4, the CoFe2O4 powder obtained above was simply placed in the atmosphere of hydrogen and argon mixture and calcined at 600 °C for 1 h. 2.2 Materials characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using a Rigaku D/Max III diffractometer under copper K α radiation with a wavelength of 1.5418 Å. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was characterized with a feld-emission scanning electron microscope (Hitachi S-8100). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), and high-angle annular detector dark-field based scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) were obtained on a FEI TalosF200x system at high acceleration voltage of 200 kV. N2 adsorption-desorption measurement was recorded with a Micromeritics ASAP2460 analyzer. Raman spectroscopy was collected on Labram HR800 with laser excitation of 532 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was analyzed by a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer. X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra were carried out using the RapidXAFS-2 M (Anhui Absorption Spectroscopy Analysis Instrument Co., Ltd.) by transmission (or fluorescence) mode at 20 kV and 20 mA. 2.3 Preparation of modified separators CoFe-CoFe2O4 or CoFe2O4 (70 wt%), acetylene black (20 wt%), and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF, 10 wt%) were mixed and coated with slurry on Celgard 2400 polypropylene (PP) separator. Then, it was dried at 60 °C for 12 h. The mass loading of the coating was about 0.55 mg cm−2. 2.4 Visual LiPS adsorption and permeation Under the condition of stirring at 60 °C, Li2S and sulfur (molar ratio 1:5) were added to the mixed solution of 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) with a volume ratio of 1:1 to obtain a brown-yellow Li2S6 solution of ∼4.5 mmol L−1. A certain amount of CoFe-CoFe2O4 and CoFe2O4 (same surface area) were added to the above solution, respectively. The color change was observed after standing for a period of time. The cavities on both sides of the H-type battery were filled with an equal volume of blank DOL/DME mixture and Li2S6 solution for visual penetration testing. The effect of the separator on the LiPS diffusion was evaluated by comparing the color changes of blank solutions. 2.5 Battery assembly and electrochemical measurements The cathode material was obtained after the mass ratio of 7:3 of sublimed sulfur and carbon nanotubes (CNT) were fused at 155 °C. Then, the CNT@S (80 wt%), acetylene black (10 wt%), PVDF (10 wt%), and N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) were fully mixed and coated on Al foil current collector. After vacuum drying, the cathode with active sulfur loading in the range of 1–5.55 mg cm−2 was obtained. As-prepared sulfur cathode, Li metal foil (at the same time as the opposite electrode and reference electrode), and separator were assembled together in a CR-2032 coin battery in a glovebox filled with argon gas. When assembled, the area of the Celgard 2400 PP separator was 2.7 cm2, the area of the positive current collector was 1.13 cm2, and the area of the Li anode was 2 cm2. The electrolyte was LiTFSI (1 mol L−1) in DOL and DME (1:1, volume ratio) with 2 wt% LiNO3. In a general cell, the ratio of electrolyte vs. sulfur (E/S) was ∼20 μL mg−1. In a high loading cell, this value was ∼7 μL mg−1. Charge-discharge tests were performed on the LAND system. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS, 10 mHz to 100 kHz) tests were performed on the CHI 660E electrochemical station. For symmetrical cells, a mixture of CoFe-CoFe2O4 or CoFe2O4, conductive agent, and PVDF (8:1:1) was coated on the Al foil. Two identical electrodes were fabricated with 30 μL of Li2S6-containing LiTFSI based electrolyte. 3 Results and discussion The morphology of CoFe-CoFe2O4 after in-situ precipitation of CoFe alloy is shown in Fig. 2 (a, b). The SEM images show that the overall thickness of the two-dimensional (2D) material was ∼150 nm. The layered structure is found to consist of uniform and widely distributed cavities with thin and tightly connected walls, which was subsequently confirmed by TEM and STEM (Fig. S2). The HAADF-STEM and corresponding EDS element mapping (Fig. 2c) proved the uniform distribution of Co, Fe, and O elements. Such non-solid structure exhibited a mesoporous structure (Fig. S3). The average pore size of ∼11.6 nm was conducive to full electrolyte penetration and active site exposure [24]. The crystal structure was further analyzed by HRTEM in Fig. 2(d) and Fig. S4. The initial CoFe2O4 showed a standard (3 1 1) crystal plane parameter corresponding to a lattice spacing of 0.251 nm. After in-situ reaction, the close heterogeneous interface was clearly visible. In particular, not only the (2 0 0) crystal face of CoFe alloy with lattice spacing of 0.143 nm appeared, but also the (3 1 1) lattice of CoFe2O4 was changed. The lattice spacing increased from 0.251 to 0.253 nm. XRD in Fig. 2(e) revealed that the resulting material still showed a crystal framework of CoFe2O4 (No. 01-1121). Peaks at 30.3°, 35.7°, 43.5°, 53.9°, 57.2°, 62.7°, and 74.0° corresponded to crystal planes (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (4 0 0), (4 2 2), (5 1 1), (4 4 0), and (5 3 3), respectively. Meanwhile, the presence of CoFe alloy peaks was observed, indicating the successful precipitation of metal. Remarkably, the peak value of CoFe2O4 corresponded to a relatively obvious low-angle shift after reduction (Fig. 2f), which seemed to mean that the lattice constant became larger, and the doping of in-situ CoFe alloy caused the lattice expansion of CoFe2O4 [25,26]. According to the density functional theory (DFT) calculation (Fig. 1a), the crystal plane spacing of CoFe2O4 in the composite increased, which was consistent with the test results of HRTEM and XRD. The length of the Fe bond in the FeO6 octahedral gap was also stretched. The change of interatomic bond length would be more conducive to the interaction between metal atoms and sulfur, improving the adsorption ability of the catalyst [27]. Synchrotron radiation tests fully demonstrated the precipitation of CoFe alloy. The XANES spectra of Co K-edge and Fe K-edge are shown in Fig. 2(g, h). The spectral curve of CoFe-CoFe2O4 was located between CoFe2O4 and Co/Fe foil, indicating that the material obtained was a complex of CoFe2O4 and Co/Fe elements. In addition to the CoO/CoCo and FeO/FeFe peaks, the scattering peaks of CoFe could also be seen in the Fourier transform results of Co and Fe K-edges extended EXAFS in CoFe-CoFe2O4 (Fig. 2i, j). This suggested that alloyed CoFe was indeed present in CoFe-CoFe2O4, rather than individual Co and Fe nanoparticles. Fig. 2(k, l) demonstrates the EXAFS spectra of Co K-edge and Fe K-edge after wavelet transformation (WT-EXAFS). Different from the simple Co and Fe foils (Fig. S5), the results of CoFe-CoFe2O4 show signals that were not present in pure CoFe2O4 and were stronger than those of CoCo and FeFe foils, which were attributed to the CoFe bond [28,29]. Meanwhile, compared with CoFe2O4, the number of O atoms coordinated with Co in CoFe-CoFe2O4 is reduced, resulting in a decrease in the CoO bond of CoFe-CoFe2O4 in EXAFS. To explore the effect of heterogeneous interfaces on the LiPS adsorption behavior, the visual illustration in Fig. 3 (a) compares the Li2S6 affinity of CoFe-CoFe2O4 and CoFe2O4 with same surface area. The brown-yellow Li2S6 was preferentially adsorbed completely in CoFe-CoFe2O4, meaning that although CoFe replaced some of the more polar CoFe2O4 in the material, the overall adsorption ability of the catalyst for LiPSs did not decrease but increased. This was mainly due to the upward shift in the center of the d-band and the stretching of the bond lengths between the metal atoms [30]. The optimal configuration and binding energy of LiPSs combined with CoFe-CoFe2O4 and CoFe2O4 were further analyzed by density functional theory (DFT). The adsorption configuration shows that there is no obvious structural deformation and collapse of LiPSs (Fig. S6). The LiPS adsorption energy of CoFe2O4 after in-situ CoFe precipitation was significantly higher than that of the initial metal oxide (Fig. 3a), which was consistent with the visualized results. XPS in Fig. S7 and Fig. 3(b, c) analyzed the elemental composition and Co/Fe coordination environment changes before and after the adsorption of Li2S6 by CoFe-CoFe2O4. The 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 orbits of Co fitted two Gaussian components, which corresponded to Co2+ and Co3+, respectively. The 2p orbits of Fe were similar to those of Co, and Fe2+ (∼710.48 and ∼724.07 eV), Fe3+ (∼712.80 and ∼727.11 eV), and the two satellite peaks made up the 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 orbital energy spectra of Fe. After binding with Li2S6 molecules, the 2p orbital of Co and Fe moved in the direction of lower binding energy, which meant that the metal atoms gain electrons from LiPSs [31,32]. Fig. S8 shows the cross-section SEM of the PP separator modified by CoFe-CoFe2O4. It can be seen that the catalyst was evenly loaded on the separator surface and the thickness was about 9 μm. There was no peeling of the coating even after folding (Fig. S9). The tight and thinner coating would be more conducive to physically blocking the LiPS shuttle and facilitating electron conduction as a second current collector [33]. The visual diffusion test based on H-type electrolytic cell further verified the inhibition effect of CoFe-CoFe2O4 on dissolubility LiPSs. As shown in Fig. 3(d), the CoFe-CoFe2O4-modified separator inserted in the middle of the cell could better prevent the yellow LiPSs penetrating. However, neither the CoFe2O4-modified separator nor the initial separator could completely block the diffusion of LiPS, especially the later. In addition, the affinity between the electrolyte and the modified separator is critical. In the contact angle test (Fig. 3e), the minimum contact angle value indicated that the CoFe-CoFe2O4 modified separator obtained the strongest electrolyte affinity, which was more conducive to the smooth mass transfer process [34]. The density of states (DOS) calculation in Fig. 3(f) provides an in-depth analysis of the regulation of electron energy level of CoFe2O4 by precipitation of CoFe alloy. CoFe-CoFe2O4 across the Fermi level showed strong conductor properties that will help reduce charge transfer and electron conduction resistance [35]. The d-band center of CoFe2O4 shifts from −4.55 to −3.75 eV due to the existence of CoFe alloy. The lattice of CoFe2O4 was increased due to the strain effect from in-situ precipitation reaction, and the d-band width decreased with the increase of interatomic distance. For transition metals, the decrease of the anti-bonding orbital occupancy caused by the upward shift of the d-band center led to the improvement of the overall catalyst adsorption, which was consistent with the visual adsorption test [36]. The projected crystal orbital Hamiltonian population (pCOHP) of SS bonds in adsorbed polysulfides revealed the positive effect of increased adsorption of CoFe-CoFe2O4 on the catalytic conversion activity of LiPSs (Fig. 3g). The average integral of CoFe-CoFe2O4 below Fermi level was lower, indicating that the SS bond on its surface had more electrons filling the antibonding orbital below Fermi level, and therefore the energy was higher. This meant that the LiPS required a lower dissociation energy barrier on CoFe-CoFe2O4 [37]. Meanwhile, the SS bond on the CoFe-CoFe2O4 was stretched, which facilitated bond breaking during lithiation (Fig. 3h) [38]. These calculations all indicated that the in-situ elevation of the d-band center in CoFe-CoFe2O4 would effectively promote the rapid reaction of LiPSs. The above theoretical analysis was proved by a series of electrochemical tests. In the CV of Fig. 4 (a), all curves showed classical redox peaks, indicating the smooth progress of the LiPS reaction process. The wide signal peak at ∼2.4 V (O) represented the oxidation of polysulfide to S8, while the two cathode peaks at ∼2.3 V (R1) and ∼2.0 V (R2) represented the formation of Li2S n (4 ≤ n ≤ 8) and Li2S2/Li2S, respectively [39]. Obviously, the electrode based on CoFe-CoFe2O4 exhibited the highest response current and the lowest polarization potential (Fig. S10), which preliminarily indicated its excellent reaction kinetics. More importantly, due to the high exchange current density caused by the excellent catalytic ability of as-prepared heterojunction, the Tafel slope values fitted by CoFe-CoFe2O4 at O, R1, and R2 were 75.9, 61.8, and 92.7 mV dec−1, respectively, which were lower than those of other materials (Fig. 4b and Fig. S11). The improvement of LiPS catalytic conversion activity of CoFe2O4 by precipitation of CoFe alloy was also reflected in the symmetric cells (Fig. S12) [40,41]. In addition, the EIS (Fig. 4c) showed that CoFe-CoFe2O4 provided the smallest semicircle in the high-middle frequency region, indicating a low charge transfer resistance (R ct). It could not be ignored that the linear slope of CoFe-CoFe2O4 in the low frequency region was higher than that of the initial CoFe2O4, which might mean that the former was easier to carry out Li-ion diffusion. Therewith, Fig. 4(d, e) and Fig. S13 further display the cathode CV analysis with different separators in the range of 0.1–0.5 mV s−1. All the sweep rate square root values were linearly related with the reaction peak currents. According to Randles-Sevcik theory, the slope of the line is directly proportional to the Li-ion diffusion coefficient [42,43]. As expected, CoFe-CoFe2O4 showed the highest Li-ion diffusion coefficient (slope), which was consistent with the results in the low frequency region of the impedance spectrum. Fig. 5 (a–c) reveals the diffusion paths and energy barrier values of Li-ions on different matrix surfaces obtained from DFT analysis. The Li-ion diffusion barrier on CoFe-CoFe2O4 (0.68 eV) was lower than that on CoFe2O4 (0.83 eV). The improved kinetic behavior might be attributed to the internal electric field formed by the CoFe-CoFe2O4 heterogeneous interface [44]. The Gibbs free energy changes (ΔG) based on the reduction of sulfur to S8*, Li2S8*, Li2S6*, Li2S4*, Li2S2*, and Li2S* on different catalysts were calculated (Fig. 5d). Firstly, in the process from S8* to Li2S6*, the Gibbs free energy is in a negative spontaneous reaction stage. CoFe-CoFe2O4 corresponds to a lower free energy value, indicating that CoFe-CoFe2O4 is more conducive to the thermodynamic reaction of sulfur reduction than CoFe2O4. Additionally, in the liquid-solid transition step from Li2S4 to Li2S2/Li2S, which has slow kinetics, LiPSs exhibits a smaller free energy barrier on CoFe-CoFe2O4. This is more conducive to the nucleation reaction. CoFe-CoFe2O4 has excellent catalytic ability for the conversion of LiPSs throughout the sulfur reduction process. In order to investigate the catalytic effect of CoFe-CoFe2O4 during the key nucleation and dissolution steps, a chronocurrent test was performed at 2.05 V and the area under the curve was integrated (Fig. 5e, f) [45,46]. The CoFe-CoFe2O4 electrode provided a nucleation capacity of 108.1 mAh g−1, which was much higher than the 45.4 mAh g−1 provided by pure CoFe2O4. Moreover, CoFe-CoFe2O4 began to show current response at 362.3 s, while CoFe2O4 began to respond at 468.9 s. Compared with the nucleation ability of LiPSs, the calculated difference of decomposition energy barrier (Fig. 5g) between Li2S on CoFe-CoFe2O4 (0.12 eV) and CoFe2O4 (0.93 eV) further demonstrated the excellent catalytic activity of CoFe-CoFe2O4. This showed that CoFe-CoFe2O4 promoted the reduction of sulfur substances and achieved an efficient dynamic electrochemical reaction [47,48]. Fig. 6 (a) shows the constant current charge-discharge curves of sulfur electrodes based on different separators. Obviously, the CoFe-CoFe2O4 modified cathode obtained the highest reversible capacity and the lowest polarization voltage (0.194 V) at 0.2 C. This was consistent with the CV results in Fig. 4(a). Even at a series of higher magnification rates, it still maintained a stable charge-discharge platform and low polarization voltage (Fig. S14), which meant high sulfur species utilization and fast reaction kinetics. More importantly, in the process of multiple rate cycles and conversions, the modified sulfur cathode of CoFe-CoFe2O4 provided ultra-high specific capacity of 1390, 1111, 1014, 858, and 751 mAh g−1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 4 C, respectively (Fig. 6b), which was higher than that of initial CoFe2O4 and pure PP separator. After returning to 0.2 C, the heterostructure electrode capacity recovered to 1174 mAh g−1. However, the performance of the CoFe2O4 and PP samples under the same conditions was not ideal. The corresponding recovered capacities were only 1101 and 734 mAh g−1, respectively. The excellent rate reflected the improved reaction kinetics of the prepared CoFe alloy based heterostructure to the active sulfur species [49]. Further, the sulfur content in a single positive electrode was increased to about 72%, while the CoFe-CoFe2O4 modification layer was reduced to ∼6 μm. Its rate performance is shown in Fig. S15. The capacities were about 1095, 875, 720, 616, and 341 mAh g−1, respectively. A stabilized high capacity of 938 mAh g−1 could still be achieved after suddenly switching the testing rate back to 0.2 C. Although these capacities were lower than those of CoFe-CoFe2O4 based electrode with ∼56% sulfur, they were still substantial. This test indicated that the as-obtained heterojunction still played a positive role in the high-content sulfur cathode to a certain extent. Surprisingly, the CoFe-CoFe2O4 modified cathode was able to maintain commendable capacitye of 1034.4 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C (Fig. S16). After the rate current was increased to 0.5 C, it could also maintain a higher capacity of 937 mAh g−1 than those with the initial CoFe2O4 (835 mAh g−1) and pure PP (540 mAh g−1) at the 100th cycle, indicating that the CoFe-CoFe2O4 did more effectively inhibit the shuttle effect and promote the LiPS conversion (Fig. 6d). Although the initial capacity of CoFe-CoFe2O4 is significantly higher than that of CoFe2O4, the capacity retention rate is slightly lower than that of CoFe2O4. This might be due to the change of coordination environment on the catalyst surface during the LiPS reaction [50,51]. Both XPS and previous literature have shown the existence of CoS and FeS bonds. However, it was possible that its content was too low (only present on the surface of the material) or was amorphous, and XRD did not show a significant phase transition (Fig. S17). The appearance of this new interface might lead to a decrease in the high adsorption activity of the original CoFe-CoFe2O4, thus allowing this phenomenon to occur. Further, the long-term cyclic stability of this heterojunction based battery exhibited a high reversible capacity of 790 mAh g−1 (1.3 C) after 400 cycles with a steady average Coulombic efficiency of ∼99.8% (Fig. 6e). The corresponding capacity fading rate was only ∼0.05% per cycle. Stable operation under high loading is another challenge facing by the practical application of Li-S batteries [52]. As shown in Fig. S18, at a sulfur loading of 5.5 mg cm−2, the CoFe-CoFe2O4 optimized cathode still presented stable charging-discharging platforms. Its reversible capacity was 1288 mAh g−1, corresponding to an area capacity of 7.15 mAh cm−2. After 30 cycles, the capacity remained at 5.96 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 6c). Based on the above results, CoFe-CoFe2O4 not only provided the sulfur electrode with a higher actual capacity due to the conductivity advantage of CoFe and the heterogeneous interface electric field, but also suppressed the shuttle effect and promoted the LiPS reaction by enhancing the adsorption performance and catalytic activity. This maintained the stability of the battery during the long cycle. In particular, the slow redox reactions of complex LiPSs during the electrochemical reaction were accelerated. This generally makes the actual capacity demonstrated in this work better than that reported in the literatures on most of L-S batteries using Fe and Co as catalysts (Fig. 6h, k) [53–60]. Static LiPS penetration (Fig. 3d) preliminarily demonstrated the blocking effect of the modified separator against the shuttle effect. However, the influence of the external electric field on it needed to be considered in the actual situation. To further explore the inhibition of LiPS shuttling by CoFe-CoFe2O4, the in-situ Raman technique (Fig. S19) was used to verify the diffusion of LiPS during actual operation. Under the optimization of CoFe-CoFe2O4, the Raman spectra only showed weak signal peaks representing S5 2−/S4 2− at ∼427.4 and ∼458.2 cm−1 (Fig. 6f, g) [61]. In contrast, strong S6 2− and S5 2−/S4 2− Raman signal peaks at ∼405 and ∼456 cm−1 could be detected, and the signals were accompanied by the entire discharge process (Fig. 6i, j). Raman results during charging were similar to those of the discharge process (Fig. S20). The weaker characteristic spectrum further confirmed that the CoFe-CoFe2O4 medium on the separator was conducive to inhibiting the diffusion of LiPSs to the anode and catalyzing the rapid conversion of active sulfur species, which could prevent the formation of “dead sulfur” [62,63]. 4 Conclusions In summary, 2D CoFe-CoFe2O4 heterojunction with cavity structure was obtained by in-situ reduction strategy. Compared with the initial transition metal oxide (CoFe2O4), it showed a more positive effect on inhibiting the shuttle effect and promoting the rapid reaction of LiPSs. Based on the strain effect of in-situ precipitation of CoFe alloy in CoFe2O4 crystal phase, the d-band center was successfully elevated. The adsorption and catalytic activity of the catalyst for LiPSs were further improved. The synergistic effect of the alloy phase and oxide phase not only exerted the polarity of metal oxide but also obtained the conductivity advantage of metal phase. Meanwhile, the internal electric field of the heterogeneous interface accelerated the ion transfer. The sulfur cathode, under the combined influence, exhibited extremely high capacities of 1390 and 751 mAh g−1 at 0.2 and 4 C, respectively. It also achieved an attenuation rate as low as ∼0.05% per cycle. Even at a high loading of 5.55 mg cm−2, the area capacity could reach 7.15 mAh cm−2. More importantly, this designed in-situ adjustment strategy not only effectively improved the actual potential of Li-S batteries, but also differed from the design schemes of most existing composite structure catalysts. The latter can only make up for the shortcomings of the original catalysts by introducing the advantages of new substances. While, the introduction of the new phase (CoFe) in this strategy effectively improved the intrinsic properties of the original catalyst (CoFe2O4), which provided a new design concept for the improvement of the catalytic ability of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The slow conversion of polyphase in lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries not only intensifies the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), but also causes the continuous accumulation of inactive sulfur species, resulting in rapid capacity attenuation and sluggish dynamic performance. Herein, the promoting effect of atomic interface stress on sulfur reaction was investigated via CoFe-CoFe2O4 heterogeneous nanosheets with a cavity structure. The strain force induced by the in-situ precipitation of CoFe bimetallic alloy in oxide matrix increased the d-band center, which was conducive to the interaction between catalyst and LiPSs. The sulfur cathode based on this two-dimensional (2D) nanosheet design showed an extremely high capacity of 751 mAh g−1 at 4 C. Even with a sulfur loading of 5.55 mg cm−2, its area capacity was still as high as 7.15 mAh cm−2. Meanwhile, the enhanced stability greatly improved the practical potential of Li-S batteries.
